texts.definition: Choices players need to make that either set their own individual gains against each others or against the gains of a social group they belong to.
markups: <style="Definition">Choices players need to make that either set their own individual gains against each others or against the gains of a social group they belong to.</style>

Games where players belong to teams, alliances, or other types of groups that are supposed to cooperate can cause problems for those players because they might exist actions that would benefit them individual but harm the larger group.

This creates a <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> for the players in that even though cooperation would be beneficial in the long run for all involved parties, the players' have the  possibility to reaping a shorter term rewards by acting egoistically or betraying the other players.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> have been the focus of several board and card games. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Republic%20of%20Rome">The Republic of Rome</link></style>, players compete against each other to have the largest faction in the Rome, but at the same time have to stop barbarians from invading the empire. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/So%20Long%20Sucker">So Long Sucker</link></style> players do not have to cooperate but they game mechanics force them to entry alliances and pacts to be able to perform actions, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style> is balanced so they are likely to have and break deals later.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

Creating <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> consist creating <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> that pair <style="Link"><link="individual-rewards">Individual Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="individual-penalties">Penalties</link></style> against <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Penalties</link></style> - this often takes the form of <style="Link"><link="asynchronous-collaborative-actions">Asynchronous Collaborative Actions</link></style>. These are often combined with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Imperfect%20Information">Imperfect Information</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="delayed-effects">Delayed Effects</link></style> to add <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> by postponing or making it more difficult or impossible to notice how other players have acted.

Quite obviously games that are supposed to have <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> need to have others populating the social groups; this provides a way to change the relations between players in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> but can also be designed for players by using <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>. There are several well-known basic types of <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style>: <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style> (see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Intrigue">Intrigue</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/So%20Long%20Sucker">So Long Sucker</link></style>), the ''Prisoners' Dilemma'', and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tragedy%20of%20the%20Commons">Tragedy of the Commons</link></style>.

The ''Prisoners' Dilemma'' is the classic example used in game theory and its name comes from the fictional situation of two prisoners accused of conspiring in two crimes, one minor crime for which their guilt can be proven without any confession, and a major crime for which the guilt can be proven only with one or more confessions. The prosecutor gives both prisoners the same deal: if both confess (which can be seen as an example of <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>), they both go to jail for five years (a <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalty</link></style>); if only one of them confesses, he goes free and the other goes to jail for 10 years (a <style="Link"><link="individual-rewards">Individual Reward</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="individual-penalties">Individual Penalty</link></style> respectively). Finally, if both refuse to confess, they both go to jail for one year (also a <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalty</link></style>). The core of the dilemma is that even though the option where both prisoners refuse to confess is better for them, for each of them there is a risk that the other will confess, and playing it safe by confessing leads to a situation where both prisoners end up in jail for five years. The design of Prisoner's Dilemma is shows how players can be tempted to not accept a certain <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalty</link></style> for the possibility of an <style="Link"><link="individual-rewards">Individual Reward</link></style> but can also receive an <style="Link"><link="individual-penalties">Individual Penalty</link></style> for misplacing trust in another player. If both confess, they receive a worse <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalty</link></style> than if they cooperated and this makes the choice one of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>. The original Prisoners' Dilemma did not allow communication between the prisoners before making the choice. Allowing <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> complicates the situation, and introduces <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Negotiation">Negotiation</link></style>, but the issue of trust and thus the <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemma</style>, still remains.

The Tragedy of the Commons revolves around avoiding Shared Penalties of having Renewable and Shared Resources from being overused and thereby becoming depleted. These Continuous Goals become dilemmas when players either cannot stop each other from consuming the resources or may not notice the consumption. The name stems from the case where a pasture is free to use for all herdsmen of a village but where over-herding would diminish its future capacity.

The construction of the social group that helps define the <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> can be done in a couple of different ways. Although the reason for having <style="Link"><link="shared-penalties">Shared Penalties</link></style> can be arbitrary in games having <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> as the core gameplay mechanic, in others the use of <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> can lessen the will for egoistic actions. Games where <style="Link"><link="beat-leader">Beat the Leader</link></style> opportunities appear create ephemeral <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> in if one should spend efforts against the current leader which benefits all other players or if one should focus on bettering one's own position and hope others will work against the leader instead. Other social groups may rely on <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guilds">Guilds</link></style>, and thereby have <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> inherent in their structures. By making the <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> not resolvable in one step, as in the case of managing <style="Link"><link="shared-resources">Shared Resources</link></style>, the dilemmas themselves create the basis for social groups as these are needed to handle what in practice are <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style>. For any grouping that can make players have a sense of <style="Link"><link="loyalty">Loyalty</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> can be added by introducing <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Republic%20of%20Rome">The Republic of Rome</link></style> shows how <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> can be combined with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutual%20Enemies">Mutual Enemies</link></style> to create <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> as well. Another option is combining <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style>.

While Social Dilemmas can work with abstract social groups, as for example a discussion of Tragedy of the Commons concerning fishing rights don't need to provide details about individual fishermen to make sense, providing details about individuals affects by the Social Dilemmas (e.g., by making these individuals as Characters or Non-Player Characters) can make players engage in Perspective Taking and open up for them have more Emotional Engrossment in the Social Dilemmas.

Both <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> can be used to create <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style>; <style="Link"><link="tied-results">Tied Results</link></style> allows players to have to share <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or not be given them at all when ties occur (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Las%20Vegas">Las Vegas</link></style> is an example of this rule but only creates weak <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> since the social groups are not explicit). <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style> can in contrast make it impossible to share <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> even when players want to. Which of these two patterns are appropriate for a specific design however depends on the other factors related to the <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>, and how one can win the game.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>

<style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style> can be used to motivate and thematize <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> when the agents which are to have these <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> are at least partly defined by said <style="Link"><link="character-alignments">Character Alignments</link></style>.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

The way players treat <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> can be influenced by what type of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> they can have with each other. This makes it possible to modulate their behavior by providing <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, hindering <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style> or having <style="Link"><link="enforced-player-anonymity">Enforced Player Anonymity</link></style>.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

When <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> depict <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> actions rather than players', they can easily become important events in the <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> give players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to do actions for egoistic or utilitarian reasons - but these may be influenced by <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style> evoked by the relations the players' have to the other players' affected. Since performing some of the actions possible in <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> are likely to cause animosity from other players, these situations can create <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and well as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>; this is likely to make the player suffering from the <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemma</style> have to choose an explicit <style="Link"><link="social-roles">Social Role</link></style>. When players are aware of other players' <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style>, even if they only potentially are dilemmas, this affects these players' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perceived%20Chance%20to%20Succeed">Perceived Chance to Succeed</link></style> as well as create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations for them due to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Inherent%20Mistrust">Inherent Mistrust</link></style>. The possibilities for <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Inherent%20Mistrust">Inherent Mistrust</link></style> makes <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> problematic to combine with <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style>. When players resolve <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> so they do not directly benefit themselves comparably with others, this may be regarded as examples of <style="Link"><link="altruistic-actions">Altruistic Actions</link></style> even when they are actually <style="Link"><link="no-ops">No-Ops</link></style>.

When other players are aware of dilemmas and they have Communication Channels to those having the dilemmas, it is quite natural for Negotiation and Social Interaction to occur. This may also support the rise of Cooperation, Dynamic Alliances, and Social Organizations when the Social Dilemmas are not resolved immediately due to being part of Continuous Goals, e.g. managing Shared Resources as in common in the Tragedy of the Commons case.

<style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style> can occur in several ways when <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> exist: choosing <style="Link"><link="individual-rewards">Individual Rewards</link></style> over <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>, making others receive <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> while avoiding them oneself, or failing to fulfill obligations related to <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style>.

Since <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> exists both as part of gameplay and in other situations, providing it in gameplay can quite easily point to similar cases in other contexts and through this <style="CurrentLink">Social Dilemmas</style> offers a basis for <style="Link"><link="critical-gameplay-design">Critical Gameplay Design</link></style>.
